abstract.text: Create a more customized and optimized gaming experience by using matchmaking rules to find players in a real-time game.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Matchmaking rules can improve the quality of matches, reduce wait times, and increase player retention by offering a more engaging and fair gaming experience. You create rules that customize the matchmaking criteria using your game-specific properties, such as rules that match players by skill level, game mode, geolocation, and language. You can also create rules that gradually loosen the matchmaking criteria over time to find matches more quickly.

Matchmaking rules contain compound expressions that Game Center applies to groups of match requests from players of your game. You write expressions using a JSON query language referencing game properties that you submit with the match request. You design the rules around the features of your game, group them into rule sets, and assign the rule sets to queues using the

In your game code, you configure a match request to use matchmaking rules by setting its queue and game-specific properties. Then submit the match request using familiar GameKit APIs, and Game Center uses the matchmaking rules to find the best matches.

content.text: Create rule sets that contain the matchmaking rules

inlineContent.text: A rule set is a collection of matchmaking rules for finding players in a multiplayer game. Use one or more rule sets to group matchmaking rules for the different configurations, levels, or other types of features in your game. You need to create at least one rule set before you can add matchmaking rules.
First decide on a format for the reference name that uniquely identifies rule sets in your organization. For example, use a reverse-domain name service path, such as

Then decide on the minimum and maximum number of players allowed to join the matches. A valid match is any number of players between the minimum and maximum range, but Game Center assumes that more players provide a better experience, so looks for the maximum number of players first. The rule set’s

content.text: Write rich expressions using a JSON query language

inlineContent.text: In the
object, set the
field to an expression that returns either a Boolean or numeric value.
An expression is a

formatted string with Game Center matchmaking function additions. Game Center uses the expression as a query on a set of requests, depending on the type of rule and stage of the matchmaking algorithm, to find the most compatible players. The algorithm applies compatible rules first, distance rules next, followed by match and team rules.

content.text: Configure a queue for the match requests

inlineContent.text: You associate each rule set with a match request queue. Then Game Center applies the rules in the rule set to all active match requests in that queue.
Pass a reference name for the queue and a rule set to the
endpoint. Set the
field of the
object to a unique name in your organization, such as a string with a reverse-domain name prefix that is similar to your rule set reference names. Pass the
for the rule set in the
object.
If you have previous versions of your game that don’t use matchmaking rules, you can apply the same rules to match requests from those versions. Set the

field to the bundle IDs of the versions that you want to include when Game Center applies the rules. Otherwise, Game Center doesn’t match players running previous versions with current versions that specify a queue name. To create rules that include players running previous versions, see

content.text: Submit match requests to Game Center

inlineContent.text: You submit a match request using the same APIs regardless of whether you configure matchmaking rules. For example, present the
interface to enable players to invite others and automatch to fill empty spots.

code: // Present the interface where the player selects opponents and starts the game.

inlineContent.text: If you can supply properties for recipients of a match request, then implement the
protocol method to return the properties for each recipient that the local player selects in the interface.
When all the players accept their invitations and GameKit invokes the
delegate method, you can implement it to access the properties for each player that you set when creating the requests.
For more information on the matchmaking flow after you submit a request, including when to accept invitations and start gameplay, see

abstract.text: A true value.
Enable players to interact with friends, compare leaderboard ranks, earn achievements, and participate in multiplayer games.
An object that encapsulates the parameters to create a real-time or turn-based match.
The maximum number of players that can join the match.
The minimum number of players that can join the match.
A mask that specifies the role that the local player would like to play in the game.
A number identifying a subset of players invited to join a match.
The criteria for the local player that Game Center uses to find other players when using matchmaking rules.
The name of the queue that Game Center places the match request in.
The criteria for recipients of the match request that Game Center uses to find other players when using matchmaking rules.
The players to invite to the match.
An interface that allows a player to invite other players to a real-time game and automatch to fill any empty slots.
Handles when the view controller finds players for a peer-to-peer match.
Returns the properties for another player that the local player invites using the view controller interface.
Add matchmaking rules that support previous classic matchmaking versions of your game.

abstract.text: Discover and invite other players to participate in a real-time game.

doc://com.apple.gamekit/documentation/Ga.title: Finding multiple players for a game

abstract.text: Game Center applies different type of rules you create in a particular order to find the best matches.
